summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Laura Menninger and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding discovery issues in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails discuss logistical arrangements for the defense to review physical evidence (boots) and digital evidence (hard drives containing photos/videos) in Colorado, and contain detailed discussions about the classification, volume, and accessibility of 'Highly Confidential' photographic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's Office to arrange review of discovery materials, including hard drives and boots, and raising numerous issues about the production and classification of evidence.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed as a recipient (Cc) on several emails regarding discovery conferral in US v. Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case US v. Maxwell. The emails discuss her right to review discovery materials and the logistical challenges of providing her access at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to an order (Dkt. No. 322) that is the subject of a meet and confer.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Listed as a recipient (Cc) on an email from Laura Menninger regarding photo evidence and discovery problems.

connections.description: Laura Menninger is the defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, as indicated by her efforts to secure discovery review for her client.
Both are involved in the legal proceedings for US v. Maxwell, with Menninger as defense counsel and Pagliuca as a contractor for the prosecuting office, communicating about discovery logistics.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: The trial for Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021, as mentioned in the context of planning for discovery review deadlines.

events.title: Coordination for Evidence Review in Colorado
events.description: Email exchange finalizing plans for defense counsel Laura Menninger to review hard drives and boots at the FBI office in Colorado before the items are shipped back to New York.

events.title: Defense Evidence Review in New York
events.description: The defense team met in New York the week of April 13, 2021, to review evidence, including 'highly confidential' hard drives, but encountered technical problems with file readers.

locations: 4624 Central Denver (FBI office location in Colorado for evidence review)
Denver, CO 80203 (Office address of Laura Menninger at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C.)
New York, NY (Location of U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and where some evidence must remain)
500 Pearl (Likely a reference to 500 Pearl Street, a federal courthouse or office in NYC)
Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) (Where Ghislaine Maxwell was held and attempted to review discovery)
keyFacts: The government possessed approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence, and an additional ~34,000 'Highly Confidential' images/videos from Epstein's devices.

A significant discrepancy existed between an initial verbal estimate of ~2,100 'nude' images from Epstein's devices and an FBI report indicating ~33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos, which the prosecution apologized for as an unintentional mistake.

The defense faced major technical hurdles reviewing discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, unreadable file formats on the MDC laptop, and the inability to match photos with their associated metadata.
Physical evidence included 'boots' that were recently taken into evidence and were being shipped to Colorado for the defense's review before being returned to New York.

The prosecution defined 'Highly Confidential' material broadly to include any nude, partially-nude, or sexualized depictions, not limited to child pornography, requiring in-person review under FBI supervision rather than providing copies to the defense.
